11 Things I Should Regret This Holidays -- But Don't

In no particular order:

1."When I visit you in the asylum, people are going to point fingers and whisper 'That's the one who broke Jonny!'"
PING: I think you, Jarrel and I should get married. And I also think you should get pregnant.
JONNY: ...
PING: Not now. But, y'know, later! Our babies would be awesome. They could take over the world. We owe it to the universe.
JONNY: My younger brother is reading over my shoulder. My pure and uncorrupted brother.
PING: Hi Jonny's brother! I think your brother would make a good Mom!
JONNY & PUREE OF BROTHER: ...
PING: The long silence is mildly disconcerting.
JONNY: We are contemplating the best and most efficient way of committing suicide.

PING: Hey Jarrel! Jonny, tell Jarrel my Brilliant Idea!
JONNY: Oh god. This is the part where I jump out a conveniently placed window.
JARREL: Pray.
PING: Jonny, if you don't tell Jarrel, I will scar your innocent brother with horrific tales of mpreg.
JARREL: ... Mpreg?
JONNY: Ping wants to marry you kthxbai
PING: No, no, he got it all wrong.  I think you, Jonny and I should get married!
JARREL: You can only marry Jarrel Clone Number 23. Clones 1 to 22 object violently.
PING: Jonny, you come talk sense to the man!
JONNY: Jonny has jumped. Please leave a message after the beep.

JARREL: Jonny, you realise that hell is probably ruled by more bsatards than you can count.
JONNY: WHAT MAKES YOU THINK I AM GOING TO HELL
JARREL: (continuing undeterred) And also, that half of those bastards are probably controlled by Ping.

JONNY: Leave and come back in 300 years! AND TAKE PING WITH YOU.
JARREL: Um. No. She's kinda scary.
PING: How am I scary? I'm practically harmless!
JARREL: Practically harmless, theoretically fatal.


2. The Icon
Picture of toy bunny. In hands of evil scientist.  Huge red letters saying JARREL SEAH with arrow pointing to ...
... the bunny. (Available upon request)


3. Backups
PING: (researching on social capital) Apparently, getting married produces the happiness equivalent of quadrupling your annual income.
PING: Hmmm. In light of this new evidence, I may have to reconsider my lifestyle policies.

PING: (mid-rant) -- and I don't understand women at all. Or worse, men who behave like women. They're women-hating half-men! -- Hang on. Daryl?
DARYL: ... Yes?
PING: Will you be my backup?
SERA: Your what?
PING: My backup. If neither of us is married by the time we're 40, we'll marry each other.
DARYL: Okay. I'll do it for the flat.
PING: Oh good! So counting my Godbrother, Daryl and composer dude, that makes it three backups.
SERA: Ping. This is a bad idea. What happens if all your backups get married before 40?
PING: (patiently)That's why there are three of them.
SERA: Yes but they could still all end up hitched to other people --
PING: Sera, Sera. I am already distrait. Do you really want to make me cry?


4. Introducing Albert
PING: Have I introduced you to Albert?
DARYL: No. Who is this Albert?
PING: He's the spirit of an All-American Frat Boy residing in my head. He's responsible for all the crude remarks that pop up in my conversation late at night!
DARYL: I see. And when did you discover that this.. Albert was in your head?
PING: A few days ago. But I trust him implicitly. We have a special connection.


5. Giving Stuffed Toys Identity Crises
I know that good girls are grateful to their alma maters. And show this appreciation by returning to vist. (This may explain why Santa is not planning to visit this year.) And it's not that there weren't good things. It's just that the bad things outnumbered the good things and are in the process of packing their innards into air-tight containers and sending them to their mothers.

THE MOTHER: (holding up teddy bear) Hey Ping, isn't this cute?
PING: ... Why is it wearing a pinafore? Take it away! Begone, foul beast!

[A week later]
PING: (cuddling a toy bear) Wow, you are so cute! But my delightful adorable stranger, from whence did you show up in our flat?
THE MOTHER: That's the bear that used to be in a pinafore.
PING: .... You lie to me.
THE MOTHER: You like to think.

PING: (glancing down at bear) All right, Teddy. Clearly, you came from a traumatic background where they forced you into a life of transvestism. But it's all right, you're with me now, everything is going to be okay.
THE MOTHER: It's name is Bear Bear. And it is a girl. And what are you doing to my bear?
PING: I'm giving it an identity crisis.(Putting the bear on all fours and bending back his ears) Do you know, Ted, you look like a dog when you do this? I think it suits you.


6. Inappropriately Titled Word Documents
BRIAN: Ping, can I borrow your laptop?
PING: Mm.
BRIAN: (A few minutes later) Ping, why is there an 'Indecent Proposal' on your desktop?
PING: That's my EE proposal!

PING: Ahaha, I am so efficient! I have revised and sent out my third extended essay proposal to my supervisor! ... Oh no. Oh no, no, no.
SERA: What?
PING: I may have forgotten to re-title the word document before sending it.
SERA: ...
PING: Okay. I might end up with no EE supervisor but I think a restraining order before turning 18 is still an accomplishment.


7. (In)formal Documents
Now the real reason why there are no updates is because I was interning at the Prime Minister's Office for just over a month. And most of it is confidential. But what I can say is, I am not built for confinement to a desk. ( I think this should be considered a legitimate handicap. I think I should be entitled to welfare benefits because this will no doubt severely restrict my job options.) Eventually, after bemoaning the 'restricted horizons of my desk' and arranging colourful post-its in pretty fan-shaped arrangements across my desk, my pent up eccentricity seeps into my work. Against my best judgment.

PING: (writing report) Telecommunications reduces both loneliness and face-to-face interaction. Hmm. "Like God, telecommunications giveth and telecommunications taketh away!"

PING: I believe summaries should be informative and entertaining. So, insightful direct quotes are no doubt in order! 
"We do not know how one liberates people happy in their servitude."
"We do not suggest, as some do, that the lower class child is being culturally raped when taught correct English.”

"Neighbourhood crime watch groups [...] are like sociological Astroturf, suitable only where the real thing won’t grow.”

UNAMUSED SUPERVISOR: Your paper read very well as an opinion piece. But there are some words we do not use when writing documents for the public service.


8. Alternative Career Plans
FRIENDLY FELLOW INTERN: (Attempts to make polite conversation, oh little did she know) So what do you plan to do after you graduate?
PING: Well, seeing as how my internment -- I mean, internship experience -- has taught me that I may not be suitable to certain jobs, I have contingent plans for alternative careers!
FELLOW INTERN: Such as...?
PING: I was thinking of being a country songwriter. "I Need You (Like An Archer Fish Needs A Rocket Launcher)!" Or something like "Your Snores Are Like Artillery Shells -- They Make My Heart Go Boom Boom Boom!" 
FELLOW INTERN: That's... interesting.
PING: Or starting a cafe with an exclusive clientele of dominating corporate women. All my waiters and barristers would be meek or submissive or hapless teenage boys! It makes good business sense. I could recruit from university undergraduates who need to pay tuition fees. And the cafe could be a front for.. corporate assasination, I suppose. At very special fees.
FELLOW INTERN: (smiles weakly)
PING: Actually, you look like the sort of lady who could use a latte served by an adorably hapless waiter with a delicate bone structure!


9. Scientific Experiment
PING: (hacks, cough, sniffles)
PING: Bleh. I don't feel so good. I think I might be ill.
ANONYMOUS COMPANION HENCEFORTH TO BE DUBBED 'THE FROG': You look really sad.
PING: (rising annoyance) I hope it's contagious.
THE FROG: (steps back)
PING: Actually, I should probably experiment to check.
THE FROG: What do you -- mmmppf!
THE FROG: ...
THE FROG: ... Did you just kiss me?
PING: If you don't fall terribly ill in the next week or so, we will know that I do not, in fact, have the plague.

Ladies (and boys with similar tastes), remember those children's fairytales tell you about frogs that turn into princes? Yeah, well. They lied.


10. The SATS
PING: (waltzes in for SATs with zero preparation)
PING: (staggers out approximately five hours later)
JONNY: How was it?
PING: I died at the Math. I could not do SAT Math questions. I am a HL Math student. GG.
JONNY: But I bet the vocab was really easy for you right!
PING: It was okay. But I was kind of distracted because the girl sitting next to me was really pretty!
JONNY & HERRICK: ...
PING: (defensively) But she was really tall and she was wearing this long flowy black dress so when she sat down it fell into all these pretty Baroque-y folds...
JONNY & HERRICK: ...
PING: Those folds would have any woman weak!

JARREL: How were SATS?
PING: Awful. I wrote a whole paragraph insulting Mother Teresa in my essay.
JARREL: You'll do well for the essay then.

A tip for those going to take the SATS: Jarrel was right.


11. This Livejournal. For obvious reasons.

I think that there is something to be said about early education on the birds and the bees. In fact, I would consider this something of a public service announcement. Based, of course, on personal experience.

My family -- by which I really mean my mother -- has always felt that this was an important aspect of our upbringing.

PING: It's embarrassing. My little brother is racist. I cannot face the world.
TINY RACIST BROTHER: What has my being racist got to do with you?
PING: Our family values are few and far in between so I suggest that we at least try to uphold what little we have!

THE MOTHER: We have family values? (amused) And what would those be...?
PING: RACISM IS BAD.
THE MOTHER: And...?
PING: ORGANISED RELIGION IS A CHOICE.
THE MOTHER: That's only two.
PING: ... BUY LOW, SELL HIGH!
THE MOTHER: That's three.
PING: Um um. Oh, I know! IT'S OKAY TO BE GAY.
TINY RACIST & HOMOPHOBIC BROTHER: I object, I object!
THE MOTHER: Four is not a lot.
PING: One more, one more... CONTRACEPTION FTW!

This exclamation, of course, precipitated a conversation on what happens when you don’t use contraception. At which point, my Mother feels it apt to launch into yet another graphic description of how we were born.

THE BROTHER: Isn’t it kinda gross to have a human being coming out of your butt?
THE MOTHER: How many times must I tell you, it’s not the butt, it’s the vagina. RESPECT MY VAGINA. IT GAVE YOU LIFE.
THE BROTHER: No! I still believe that Daddy gave birth to me!

THE MOTHER: I don’t know why your brother keeps thinking that your father gave birth to him. He’s been thinking this since he was… six?
PING: Because that’s about the time you started telling him the traumatic birthing stories. With graphic details about your epidermal spinal tap.

I will have you all know that my failure to update was an act of defiance. Truly, I bravely resisted updating under pain of death.

JIA LONG: PING. Do you want to die?
PING: Not at the moment, why?
JIA LONG: THEN UPDATE YOUR BLOG.

Far be it from me to disagree with a man almost twice my size. Thus, I find myself here. Updating. But you must forgive me if I sound strained for I have taken ill. My soul is weak, my throat is sore, I do not update anymore!

Despite my affliction of the body -- I consider afflictions of the soul part of my, ah, natural charm -- I have been out the past two nights indulging in an expensive hobby. By which I mean watching plays and not, contrary to popular belief, anything vaguely related to the deflowering of virgins.

AMIL: (darkly) I've heard stories about you. You go around deflowering people. Like some serial virgin deflower.
PING: I do not. Bingei, you are a gentleman. This is the part where you stand up for me and defend my honour!
BINGEI: Er, what's deflowering?
AMIL: It's like a bush. No, a bush fire. And it spreads and lays waste to the surroundings leaving complete destruction in its wake!
BINGEI: ... Huh? I don't get it.

BINGEI: I still don't get what deflowering means.
SERA: (deadpan) It means having sex with a virgin.
BINGEI: ... Oh. Oh.
PING: Wow, Sera. You've just accomplished in one minute what a table-full of Drama Ex Co members failed to do in fifteen.

PING: Flare or flair?
SIR: Fling?
PING: PING NO FLING.
SIR: Bwahahahaha.
PING: Ping no fling! ... Pling! Pling!  From now on, pling shall be the sound made when people are making violent protests against VILE ACCUSATIONS.

If you've happened to hear any wild stories regarding myself and deflowered virgins, deviant sexual behaviour etcetera, all I have to say is "Pling! Pling! Pling! Pling!"

At any rate, I think such a hobby would pale in comparison to the activities of my other family members.

THE MOTHER: Your Father says I am dabbling in The Occult.
THE FATHER: She's doing past-life therapy and reading fairy cards. It is occult.
PING: Momma, all I have to say is, if you must be involved in The Occult, can you please try something a bit more... hardcore.
STRANGER AT BORDERS: (shifts away surreptitiously)
PING: Look! Here's REAL Tarot cards! For grown ups! None of that fairy card nonsense, thank you. 

Then I met up with Bryan and we set off on a quest to find blue elephants. 

PING: Why blue elephants, Bryan? Why not pink rhinoceros? They're so much more attractive!
BRYAN: Because I promised her I'd buy her a blue elephant.
PING: Okay, well, did you specify the dimension of the elephant? Because I gotta tell you, there's a big difference between finding a 2D blue elephant and a 3D one.

So we set off innocently to find blue elephants, venturing bravely into furniture stores for small children. I can't say I didn't try to be helpful.

PING: Oh, forget the ugly blue elephant stuff toy! Give her this colourful rat! It's pink and glittery -- and oh my god, that is the ugliest thing I have ever seen. YOU MUST BUY IT FOR HER. Look! Everybody wants a deformed chihuahua!

Then we stumbled into this other store and, lo and behold, I saw the only piece of furniture that I've ever wanted as much as my couch.

PING: It is a blue turret-like tent structure. With hideous curtains. For small children to sit inside! It is the most hideous and gaudy thing I have ever seen. I MUST HAVE IT.

All right. I am going to interrupt myself because I am easily distracted and I want to watch Hugo Weaving in drag again. Priscilla, Queen of the Desert!

So the worst is over -- all right, that is a damned lie. ("An odious, damned lie; upon my soul, a lie, a wicked lie. She false with Cassio! -- did thou say Cassio?") The worst is, of course, the results release but that is a tragedy for another time. And as for being false with Cassio, well, the only Cassio I have been false with is my Casio calculator. 

Now I am lounging indolently on the sofas at the Esplanade library cafe, having sent out an email to my EE supervisor and awaiting an irate (but perfectly eloquent!) response in return. Sera has fallen asleep next to me, having acquired my sweater as a blanket by virtue of ... looking melancholic and cute. There is a drained pot of chamomile tea (thank the Gods for natural sedatives) on the table and David Hare plays scattered around. The last is my doing, I fear. In any case, this is perfectly peaceful and companiable and I can imagine living like this, oh yes. Unfortunately, Sera has repeatedly rejected my marriage proposals ("... but it's legal in Canada!") so I am resigned to mere platonic (as opposed to domestic) arrangements. 

You might wonder if the exams have turned me into a maudling fool. That may perhaps be true. Or this strange tranquility (as opposed to the usual strain of hysterical lunacy to which I trust, dear readers, you have become accustomed) may be a product of the chamomile tea. Moreso the latter, I think. 

This indicates continuity from the exam week, which was a constant search for The Knockout Blow, ie. the ideal sedative. Actually, for somebody who does not take exams as seriously as she should (please refer to previous post), you might wonder why I need sedatives. Unfortunately, I have a hyperactive inner-monologue that is only amplified by the exam month because I actually reach home at reasonable hours! Before the sun sets! And there are no errands or assignments to worry about and one is gloriously, gloriously free. And since I am no longer perpetually exhausted or distracted and am stuck, alone, with my internal monologue for extended periods of time... I realise that, wow, am I a difficult person to co-exist with. (So this is how you guys feel all the time, huh?) I was, at some point, contemplating beating my brain repeatedly with a large stick but it struck me that I might actually, maybe, just perhaps, need my brain for the exams.

For those of you looking to de-stress, let me introduce you to some methods I attempted. You may gauge the level of success yourself. 

1. Chant mantras. 
I was sitting with Yam and Sera at Dover MRT and rambling and gesturing hysterically as I am wont to do when, out of nowhere, this nice Chinese lady comes up to me and begins to speak. 

LADY: (prattles in rapid dialect-accented Mandarin)
PING: (incomprehension)  
LADY: (repeats herself, smiling, and trots off peaceably) 
SERA: Oh, I get it! She was telling you not to get frustrated and to chant Buddhist sutras to calm yourself.
PING: But I wasn't frustrated. I was talking about American sitcoms! 
[...]
PING: Hang on. My Mother is a New Age hippie. I *know* Buddhist mantras, dammit, I have to listen to Tibetan Buddhist chants in the car rides to school. What was that one about the diamond and the lotus again? 
PING: I.. can't.. remember. Oh my god, I have no New Age Hippie cred! 

[Some time later]
PING: Okay, guys, don't panic! Say it with me: Om Mani Padme Hum. 
DARYL, SERA, PING: (chorus) Om Mani Padme Huuuummmmm....
BEWILDERED PASSERBYS: (give funny looks at bunch of Methodist schoolchildren sitting on floor of Dover MRT)
PING: (sagely) We are not concerned by your judgmental looks, O Child People. We are at peace. Our jewels are in their lotuses.


2. Write plays chronicling your suffering.

PING: Man, you should see my History notes. They make no sense. They've got all these weird snide comments scribbled everywhere, like "Hitler's domestic policies were not entirely kosher... hahaha, irony".
SUNNO: (contemplative) Well, we could put that in a play but we'd get shot in our sleep.
PING: Not unless we fly away to the Palestinian territories before that! Controversy does wonders for box office sales, you know. It would be box office blitzkrieg! 
SUNNO: ... Palestine?! I can see it now. We could do touching Middle East-based Ho with Heart plays and give them names like 'The Gaza Strip (I have always relied on the kindness of wealthy foreign men)'. 

3. Throw scenes.

Post-Honours day emceeing
JONNY: You sound like a guy over the mike!
PING: ... what do you mean I sound like a guy. 

PING: (goes around interrogating people for their opinion)
SHAW SHAW: You sound like a smoker. You know, low and husky. Tsk tsk, what have you been doing... 
SIR: Why so husky? 
SAM: Oh, Ping has a bedroom voice! (At this point, I interject with a "WHY ARE YOU PAWING AT MY ARM? GET THEE BEHIND ME!") 
LLOYD: No. But my standards are low.

PING: Jonny, I do not sound like a guy!
JONNY: (polite but obviously lacking in self-preservation instincts) I'm sorry, I'm sorry -- but you do!
BUNCH OF JONNY'S FRIENDS: (gather round to watch their hapless friend fend off a hysterical woman)
PING: (espies a familiar face in circle of friends) Juzzy. Tell me, do I sound like a guy over the mike?
JUZZY: (obviously has self-preservation instincts) No. Of course not.
PING: Thank you, Juzzy. (whirls on Jonny) See? SEE? Now, Jonathan, you get out and don't come back until you learn how to talk to a woman! (walks off, pauses, turns) Bye, Juzzy!

[After the debacle]
JONNY: Yes, Ping. Even your scant femininity causes me to die. 

4. Listen to sad songs

ZI YANG: (glancing at Ping's history notes) What is this... "There was a need for a Brave New Tsar, hahaha"
PING: Okay, I have no idea what I was talking about.
[Five minutes later]
PING: Okay, I have a page-full of notes that has lots of important looking scribbles on it but I really don't know what I was talking about! ... I need to listen to soothing music. "Be thou my vision, Oh Lord of my Heart~" 
ZI YANG: Oh my god. Hang on, the last time.. was it you who was obssessing over Be Thou My Vision?
PING: "Naught be all else to me, save that Thou aaaart!"
ZI YANG: YES IT WAS YOU 

PING: (listening to Billy Joel's 'And So It Goes', which is a really sad song, by the way) 
CONCERNED STUDYMATE: (leaning over) Ping, are you tearing over (peers at notes) aerial bombing? 

So, what do you guys do to de-stress? Enact scenes from vintage movies in public places? Have competitions seeing who can spring the most cliches into innocent conversations? Totter around Ikea because you want to be unfaithful to your couch? Not that I have contemplated doing any of the above, aha aha!

Some time back, we had to do a written commentary on an excerpt from The Thin Red Line, in which the author illustrates, in loving detail, the "almost sexual, morbid curiosity" with which a platoon of soldiers observe their injured comrades.

Cut to today, some time before our English paper, when I was tormenting poor Jonny with my talk of how Huck's perception of Emmeline Grangerford obviously revealed the perspective of an adolescent "on the cusp of sexual awakening".

JONNY: But she's dead!
JIA LONG: There's a word for that, right? ... Necrophilia.

Not quite. So there I sat, pondering on how one could accurately describe Huck's feelings towards Emmeline Grangerford -- and then it hit me.

PING: Sera. What will you give me if I can work into my essay a line that describes Huck's feelings towards Emmeline as an "almost sexual, morbid curiosity"?
SERA: Hmm. I don't think you'll actually have an opportunity so... one week's supply of yoghurt.
PING: YOU ARE ON.

With a newfound sense of purpose, I trudged into the exam hall and lo! There was a question on suffering.

PING: (thinks) Gee, I can do this. I'm sitting for my Promos, I know all about suffering.
[Half an hour to the end of paper]
PING: (thinks) You know, technically, Emmeline is a suffering character. She's your classic Western emo-kid! She is a tortured arteeest. She is all about the suffering.
PING: (scribbling madly) Ehehehehe. "... Emmeline Grangerford, whom Huck views with an almost sexual, morbid curiosity...."

Note to self: Must start taking exams more seriously.

In retrospect, I probably should't have had two cups of coffee before the paper. But no matter! If I fail English, I will at least be able to drown my sorrows for a week in blissful, yoghurt-y numbness.

... PRAY FOR US SINNERS

Ping, Sera, Shiru and the two History Sirs are randomly positioned around the lecture theatre.

That is to say, everybody is seated with great dignity, with the exception of Ping who is bouncing from podium to seat for no apparent reason.

PING: (cheerfully sends Shiru an SMS, despite her being in the same lecture theatre) "Hello! Are you alive!"
SHIRU: (raising phone, long-suffering) Ping, what is this?
PING: Hee!
SHIRU: Check your phone.
PING: (Opens SMS, reads) "No."
PING: ... Schrodinger's Shiru! She is both alive and not alive at the same time.

SIR: Pingpingping, are you coming for consulation tomorrow?
PING: Yes! [...] Although I will be a zombie, but I will come!
SIR: Why zombie?
PING: So I can be Schrodinger's Ping! I am both alive and dead... at the same time.
SIR: You mad.
PING: That's what the voices in my head tell me too.

In other news, The Mother is reading a book entitled "How To Be An Adult". Suddenly, the domestic events of the past two years take on a new light: It all makes sense now!

A while ago, I remarked that perhaps it was time for me to go on hiatus and Grow Up. Events of late have shown, however, that perhaps Growing Up now would be a bit... premature, as it were. And it is in fact possible to combat the Forces Of The Universe with minimal resulting trauma without doing so!

Stage 1: Ominous Foreshadowing
Post-common tests and the intensive rehearsals leading up to FoA.

PING: We have beatboxing! Geeky dance sequences! Boys dressed as girls being hit on by boys! Better yet -- boys dressed as girls being hit on by other boys dressed as girls!
THE MOTHER: I am starting to have my doubts about your drama activities
PING: Crossdressing is a sacred tradition.

IZZY: I HAVE TO WEAR SPANDEX!
CLASS: Izzy in spandex? Tickets, please!

PING ON STONER MUSIC: We got a killer scene here, man!
FORCES OF THE UNIVERSE: Yeah, but you just wait for the shit to hit the fan...

Stage 2: Sense of Impending Doom
PING: But don't worry! I have a Cunning Plan!
VOO: ...
PING: Your liberal use of ellipses suggests a disturbing lack of faith in my Cunning Plans.

KISMETSAYS: Your life is a Divine Comedy!
PING: Rapidly degenerating into an Inferno.

Stage 3: Attempts to Preserve Dignity
[Costume-making]
PING: You are sewing... sequinned garbage bags?
IZZY: As long as it's not spandex, I'm happy!

[Practicing dance sequences]
SLOO: I'm failing at the krumping. I don't have the equipment: I've got no ass and no chest!

[Ping at Esplanade library]
SENIOR FROM CONVENT DAYS: Oh hi, Ping! Fancy seeing you here. (Glances at cooking books on table) Those aren't yours, right?
BONG & SLOO: (return to table)
PING: Nope. She's the baker! Hey, Sloo, did you find the sewing books?
SLOO: No.
SENIOR: Wait. So she bakes, he sews... what do you do?
PING: (clutching at script with as much dignity as she can muster) I read.

VOO: Ow! Why are you hitting me?
PING: Because I'm stressed.
VOO: If I die, my DNA will be under your fingernails.

Stage 4: Turn to God.. or not
SHAW SHAW: Why is Maths important?
JIA LONG: Because God says so.
PING: Man, that's like the ultimate appeal to authority.
SHAW SHAW: You just reduced the basis of my religion to a logical fallacy. Wah lao!

PING: (stuck in the middle of Sera & Shaw Shaw's theological discussions) Why is it that I'm always between the two of you when you're having intense theological discussions?
SIR: You are destined to be the Other Woman in their lives.
PING: That sucks. I don't even get to buy an HDB flat, right...
SIR: No, you don't. That's reserved for her.

Stage 5: And the shit hit the fan.
One week before production, Ping flies up to Penang because some one close passed away. Everybody is very supportive and understanding.

JIA LONG: Group hug! I promise I won't crush you.

It transpires that the Family has very strange ways of coping with grief. (As they do with everything else.)

There is the fraught tension:
THE MOTHER: Hurry up! Go go go!
PING: Mom, we are disembarking from a plane, not executing a military operation.

The guilt and confession:
THE MOTHER: Your Momma is not very good at being maternal.

The long silences and inappropriate dinner table conversations:
[All staring at the cousins' dog]
THE MOTHER: This dog wants everybody's love.
PING: The dog is a ho.
THE MOTHER: The dog is a whore?
PING: No, a HO.
THE MOTHER: Oh. I was wondering why you called the dog a whore.
THE PREVIOUSLY UNNERVINGLY SILENT FATHER: ... The dog is a bitch.
PING: Technically, he is right.

The inappropriate funeral parlour conversations:
THE BROTHER: (doing homework) What is 'made out'?
CONSERVATIVE TWENTY-FOUR YEAR-OLD COUSINS: !!!
THE BROTHER: What?
PING: (snapping) It's the past-tense of make out.
CONSERVATIVE COUSINS: (scandalised silence)
THE BROTHER: Oh. What is 'make out'?
PING: I believe it is the paltry teenage version of sex.

Then we flew home and there were madcap rehearsals and performances and everything worked out in the end. And in the spare moments where I was not comatose or rehearsing, my friends and I did the strangest things to keep me occupied or distracted.

Including sitting in the children's section of a library and doing Freudian & Marxist readings of A Dog Named Spot.

PM Lee says that "heterosexuals should set the tone of society". He's right - heretosexuals do. That's why gay sex is still illegal. That's why 'gay' is a taunt used to ridicule and demean in primary schools.

It isn't right for the majority to use the law as a whip to impose personal or religious beliefs on the rest of society. This isn't about whether people are born gay or choose to become gay, or whether homosexuality is depraved.

You see, promiscuity is widely acknowledged as sinful and depraved -- but it isn't illegal. People will question your judgment and that's their perogative, but nobody will question your freedom to lead a hedonistic lifestyle. A heterosexual hedonistic lifestyle, that is.

This is about respecting human rights. It's about respecting people's freedom to make lifestyle choices. Especially when their lifestyle choices don't directly harm you.

At some point, the discrimination will stop. For the times they are a-changing!
